p: The immunological mechanisms underlying severe liver injury due to HEV infection in pregnancy are not yet well understood. It has been reported that liver injury resulting from HEV in the general population is due to immune-activated CD8, NK and NKT cells in the liver as well as in peripheral circulation [ 86, 101– 103]. In HEV-positive pregnant patients with FHF, CD4 + T cell counts were lower, CD8 + T cell counts were higher and CD4+/CD8+ ratios were significantly lower than those in HEV-negative pregnant women or in controls with FHF [ 104]. However, the role of NK and NKT cells in the pathogenesis of FHF in pregnant women remains unknown. Moreover, although Th2 bias was confirmed to exist in pregnant women with HEV infection, its effect on the severity of HEV infection is unknown [ 86].
